awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Banded Together: Modern water-microbe-mineral feedbacks in the deep Archean lithosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
Microbial life is in constant contact with humans and our environment. Interactions between microbial life, humans, and our environment influence essentially every aspect of daily modern life, from the treatment of medical conditions to agricultural innovations.  These interactions show how successful microbial life can be under a wide variety of conditions, on short time scales, and at the Earth's surface.  However, scientists also have evidence that microbial life is important over long time scales and deep underground.  In this project we will investigate the strategies that microbial life uses to survive under difficult circumstances while living deep underground.  In particular, we are interested in understanding whether microbial waste products can create new space for growth, new neighborhoods for microbial life, or condemn them to inevitable death.  From our scientific observations, we will create models that will help us understand how microbial life works underground.  Our results could be useful in understanding how microbial life will affect energy extraction processes, such as hydrologic fracturing ('fracking'), and underground waste disposal for some of our worst waste streams, such as nuclear materials. As part of our project, we will form a partnership with Community and Tribal Colleges of the Great Lakes Region. This partnership will focus on engaging underrepresented groups in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. Rural Community and Tribal Colleges are primary conduits for post-secondary training and often serve as stepping stones to higher education in Native American communities of the region. We will develop and implement a hands-on summer workshop, 'The Life-Earth Connection', to be offered by our team during two consecutive summers at our field site. The workshops will provide an experiential learning opportunity that highlights the interactions of life, earth, and water through field and laboratory activities. Participants will also interact with peers and scientists in formal and informal settings to build career awareness and a professional network.
 
Through this research project, we seek to discover the mechanisms by which microorganisms interact with physical and geochemical components of the deep subsurface.  We are specifically interested in understanding the potential feedbacks that microbial metabolism has on the habitability of fractured-rock aquifer systems. Our overall approach is to conduct a hypothesis-driven study with integrated field-, laboratory-, and modeling components.  Our project leverages the experience of a collaborative scientific team that draws broadly on Earth Science disciplines: specifically, geology, hydrogeology, geochemistry, and microbiology. With a field study centered on legacy boreholes and archived cores, we will investigate Neoarchean fractured-rock aquifers of the Canadian Shield. Through this work, we will define: (1) subsurface hydrogeological and geochemical factors that support or inhibit microbial growth; (2) microbial adaptation to limiting factors through community interactions and metabolic innovation; and (3) the positive or negative feedbacks of microbial activity on the geogenic milieu and habitability. Field and laboratory data streams will be integrated, and hypotheses tested, through the development and use of a fracture-scale reactive-transport model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, our collaborative team sought to discover the mechanisms by which microorganisms interact with physical and chemical components of the deep subsurface to create feedbacks on the habitability of continental fractured-rock systems. Our field study centered on legacy boreholes and archived cores, specifically investigating Neoarchean fractured-rock aquifers of the Canadian Shield. 

We assessed the potential sources of energy for microorganisms in Neoarchean bedrock on the 27th level west drift of the Soudan Underground Mine State Park, MN, USA (713.5 meters below the surface) in Dowd et al., EPSL, 2022.  We found that energy sources for anaerobic microbes are abundant in the deep continental crust. Metabolic reactions involving methane oxidation by sulfate would yield the highest potential energy of reactions modeled in this study per mass of borehole fluid. The free energy for methanogenesis via the breakdown of dimethylamine is favorable, but the available energy per mass fluid is nearly zero, suggesting that dimethylamine may be cycled quickly to produce biological methane at Soudan. Our work represents the first identification and quantification of dimethylamine in Precambrian shield brines. Abundant methane is likely sourced by both microbial and thermogenic processes, as supported by analysis of abundance ratios, traditional stable isotopes, and doubly substituted ‘clumped’ methane isotopes. Clumped methane signatures are similar to those of presumed natural abiotic methane. Our assessment of metabolic potential energy provides a baseline for the limits of subsurface life on Earth and other planets. The high ionic strengths of the Soudan brines require the use of a semi-empirical base Pitzer/Harvie-Moeller-Weare activity model to calculate the activity coefficients of dissolved aqueous species. Applying this approach to saline deep aquifers is challenging but essential to estimating energy availability to the deep biosphere and identifying viable redox couples. Our study provides a model approach that will be helpful to other researchers working on highly saline, gas-rich, cool natural waters, including other deep continental aquifers. 

Many operational and analytical challenges limit the types of measurements that can be made in legacy boreholes. We approached this challenge in Schuler et al., GCA, 2024 in two ways. First, we examined fractures in legacy rock cores at the micron-scale to gain a “microbe’s perspective” on the geomaterials present at the rock-water interface. Second, we examined materials collected from borehole fluids at different depths along the borehole at the nano-scale to understand the intra-particle assembly of microbial cells, exudates, and minerals. By choosing the right analytical probe at the right length scale, we can learn about the physical and chemical environment in the deep biosphere. This general approach relies on a suite of complementary synchrotron X-ray microscopy, fluorescence imaging, absorption spectroscopies, and diffraction methods. The approach allows us to directly observe the texture and composition of fracture walls and biofilms to inform reactive transport models and interpretation of geochemical, microbiological, and ecological data sets. The approach that we developed for this study is novel, to our knowledge, within the deep biosphere community of researchers. Outcomes describe the composition (morphology, texture, and chemical speciation of carbon and iron) of biofilms sampled from Soudan Mine boreholes and investigate the biogeochemical iron and sulfur cycling by chemical and microbiological processes. This work is important because biofilm-hosted life likely plays a major role in deep subsurface ecosystems. Metagenomic analyses complemented this geochemical work by looking for marker genes associated with microbial metabolisms that oxidize or reduce iron and sulfur compounds.  Our work sheds new light on biogeochemical cycling in the subsurface and highlights how a combination of alternative sampling strategies and specialized geochemical analyses can shed new light on deep subsurface ecosystems. The project contributed to the training and professional development of 3 PhD students at Lehigh and one postdoctoral researcher. McDermott presents the Soudan Mine as a case study in two courses, on aqueous thermodynamics in marine systems and Earth history. Although the Soudan Mine is not marine, the high salinity of the aquifer presents many challenges that are analogous to working on cool marine brines. It is thus a useful framework to illustrate concepts of gas and mineral solubility to early career researchers, as well as the necessary differences in thermodynamic assessments of brines. Soudan mine also represents an ancient marine deposit, with relevance for the understanding of past ocean systems and continental accretionary processes.
